abstract: Shares of Baidu.com, owner of China’s most popular Internet search site, fell after the death of its chief financial officer, Shawn Wang. Mr. Wang died in an accident on Thursday, the company said in a statement on Saturday. A group of senior managers will take on his duties until a successor is named. Under Mr. Wang, Baidu’s shares soared past $400 in the United States last month, a 15-fold gain from their initial price of $27. The company has expanded its market share in China, taking 61 percent of Web queries to Google’s 24 percent, according to Analysys International in Beijing. Baidu fell $9.07, to $389.80 in New York. Baidu is the only Chinese company in the Nasdaq 100 index, which consists of the 100 biggest nonfinancial companies by market value listed on the Nasdaq.

abstract: The Royal Bank of Canada’s proposed $1.6 billion acquisition of Alabama National BanCorp was challenged by a group that claimed the Canadian bank engages in discriminatory lending. A financial advocacy group for poor consumers, Fair Finance Watch, said it asked the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va., in a letter for hearings and all documents relating to the proposed buyout. The Royal Bank agreed on Sept. 6 to buy Alabama National for cash and stock. Fair Finance Watch claimed that in 2006 Royal Bank’s RBC Centura unit denied mortgage refinance applications in Charlotte, N.C., to blacks 4.4 times more frequently than whites. The group said in the Atlanta area, RBC Centura denied home improvement mortgage applications of blacks 4.2 times more frequently than whites. A bank spokeswoman, Judi Levita, said “the lending practices of RBC Centura satisfactorily comply with all applicable requirements.”.

abstract: BATTERY RESTRICTIONS Beginning Tuesday, airline passengers cannot pack any loose lithium batteries in checked bags, though the batteries are permitted if contained within laptops, cellphones or other electronic devices, according to a new rule by the Transportation Department. The department said that loose lithium batteries can short-circuit and create a fire hazard in cargo holds. The new rule also limits to two the number of large-size spare lithium batteries that may be brought on in carry-on bags, but a department spokeswoman says that restriction applies mostly to professional and industrial-use batteries and does not affect most lithium batteries used in consumer electronics like laptops and cellphones.

abstract: Singapore’s economy expanded 7.5 percent in 2007, at the lower end of the government’s forecast range, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said. Growth eased from 7.9 percent in 2006 and is expected to slow further to as little as 4.5 percent next year. Mr. Lee, left, warned that the United States economy may enter a recession next year amid financial market turmoil. “A U.S. downturn would affect Asia too, but the impact on us would be offset somewhat by the strong momentum in the dynamic Asian economies,” Mr. Lee said. The full-year growth figure suggests that the $132 billion Southeast Asian economy may have contracted in the fourth quarter on an annualized basis, analysts said.

lead_paragraph: Jay Leno made a triumphant return to late-night television Wednesday night, easily dominating the ratings competition over his chief rival, David Letterman, and delivering one of his traditional full-length monologues  even though he was performing without his team of 19 writers.

headline.main: Leno and Guild in Dispute Over His Monologue

abstract: The National City Corporation said it was cutting its dividend by nearly half and shutting its wholesale mortgage division.
snippet: The National City Corporation said it was cutting its dividend by nearly half and shutting its wholesale mortgage division.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND (AP)  The regional bank National City Corporation said on Wednesday that it was cutting its dividend by nearly half and shutting its wholesale mortgage division, eliminating 900 jobs, because of weakened housing and credit markets.

headline.main: Regional Bank in Ohio to Trim 900 Jobs
headline.print_headline: Regional Bank in Ohio to Trim 900 Jobs

headline.print_headline: Practicing the Subtle Sell of Placing Products on Webisodes

abstract: For many small-business owners, the weeks after Christmas and New Year’s are a time to recharge after the adrenaline rush of the holidays gives way to an emotional letdown.
snippet: For many small-business owners, the weeks after Christmas and New Year’s are a time to recharge after the adrenaline rush of the holidays gives way to an emotional letdown.
lead_paragraph: FRESH off 80-hour workweeks in a sprint for holiday sales, it is little wonder that some entrepreneurs are escaping for a precious few days of sun and relaxation.

headline.print_headline: Avoiding the After-Holidays Letdown

abstract: The Ultimate Ears Super.Fi 4vi is an iPhone headset that uses proprietary technology to improve and isolate the sound coming out of your phone.
snippet: The Ultimate Ears Super.Fi 4vi is an iPhone headset that uses proprietary technology to improve and isolate the sound coming out of your phone.
lead_paragraph: As Steven P. Jobs said when he introduced the iPhone, it’s not just a phone  it’s also a music player. It stands to reason, then, that music fans will want a pair of headphones that can reproduce the highs, lows and midranges they expect from their other music devices.

headline.main: Circuits: Hi-Fi Earbuds for Hearing Less Noise and Higher Quality When Listening to Music on the iPhone
headline.print_headline: Circuits: Hi-Fi Earbuds for Hearing Less Noise and Higher Quality When Listening to Music on the iPhone

abstract: Pension funds, university endowments and other groups  exempt from paying taxes  get relief from a law intended to combat two notorious corporate tax shelters.
snippet: Pension funds, university endowments and other groups  exempt from paying taxes  get relief from a law intended to combat two notorious corporate tax shelters.

headline.print_headline: Law Amended to Shield Tax-Exempt Groups

abstract: Nokia Siemens Networks, a maker of wireless networks, agreed to buy Apertio for about 140 million euros ($206 million) to expand its subscriber data management services. Apertio has 237 employees and had sales of about 28 million euros in 2007, Nokia Siemens said. Nokia Siemens, which is a joint venture of Nokia and Siemens and is based in Espoo, Finland, expects the acquisition to close in the first quarter of this year. Apertio’s products are used by wireless and fixed phone operators. Apertio, based in Bristol, England, has operations in Continental Europe, Asia and the United States.

abstract: If you have a sneaking suspicion that the Web page you’re looking at is old and stale, you can take a peek to see when it was last updated. In Internet Explorer or Firefox, just go to the address bar while the page is displayed in your browser and type in “javascript:alert(document.lastModified)” without the quotation marks. Hit the Enter key to see a box that tells you when the page you’re viewing was updated.
lead_paragraph: If you have a sneaking suspicion that the Web page you’re looking at is old and stale, you can take a peek to see when it was last updated. In Internet Explorer or Firefox, just go to the address bar while the page is displayed in your browser and type in “javascript:alert(document.lastModified)” without the quotation marks. Hit the Enter key to see a box that tells you when the page you’re viewing was updated.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: How Stale Is That Web Page?

abstract: The Sony Bravia VPL-VW40 front projector costs $3,000 but displays images at a vertical resolution of 1,080 lines and 60 frames a second, the highest on the market.
snippet: The Sony Bravia VPL-VW40 front projector costs $3,000 but displays images at a vertical resolution of 1,080 lines and 60 frames a second, the highest on the market.
lead_paragraph: Even as the prices of L.C.D. and plasma TVs slide, high-definition projectors remain expensive  but at least they are getting considerably better. The Sony Bravia VPL-VW40 front projector, for example, costs $3,000 but displays images at a vertical resolution of 1,080 lines and 60 frames a second, the highest on the market.

abstract: Is there software to restore a Windows XP computer system to “pre-ownership” state?
snippet: Is there software to restore a Windows XP computer system to “pre-ownership” state?
lead_paragraph: Q. I’m about to give my six-year-old Windows XP computer to a friend. Short of reformatting the hard drive, is there any way to expunge my identity  my name, for instance, automatically supplied to certain forms  from the nooks and crannies of the machine? Is there software to restore a system to “pre-ownership” state?

lead_paragraph: LG’s deal with Netflix to put streaming movies on some LG televisions shows that we are entering the AOL era of Internet television. We are going to see a lot of similar announcements from the Consumer Electronics Show next week as TV makers build walled gardens of hand-picked Internet- delivered video content for their high-end sets that resemble the early online services like AOL, Prodigy and CompuServe. We’ll also see more set-top boxes with their own walled gardens, like Vudu.

abstract: The landscape for mergers and buyouts shifted drastically last summer, but one theme remained constant in 2007: If there was a big deal, Goldman Sachs was probably involved. As in previous years, the firm was the top adviser on mergers as measured by dollar volume, both globally and for deals with targets in the United States. It also ranked near the top of the heap as a participant, through its private equity arm, in leveraged buyouts.

abstract: The United Arab Emirates will keep a 30-year link between its currency, the dirham, and the United States dollar, after completing a review of its currency regime.
snippet: The United Arab Emirates will keep a 30-year link between its currency, the dirham, and the United States dollar, after completing a review of its currency regime.
lead_paragraph: The United Arab Emirates will keep a 30-year link between its currency, the dirham, and the United States dollar, after completing a review of its currency regime, said the central bank governor, Sultan bin Nasser al-Suwaidi, left. “In 12 months I can say to you that the U.A.E. will maintain the peg,” Mr. Suwaidi said. “We have come to the conclusion that the inflation problem does not lie with the peg against the U.S. dollar.” The dirham is fixed to the dollar at 3.6725. “We were studying the causes of inflation, and we came to the conclusion that the causes are not in the dirham/U.S. dollar peg, therefore we need not do anything on that front,” Mr. Suwaidi said.

headline.main: United Arab Emirates: Link to U.S. Dollar Kept
headline.print_headline: United Arab Emirates: Link To U.S. Dollar Kept

abstract: Led by higher food and energy costs, inflation in Spain accelerated to the fastest rate in more than a decade in December even after economic growth slowed.

lead_paragraph: Led by higher food and energy costs, inflation in Spain accelerated to the fastest rate in more than a decade in December even after economic growth slowed. The inflation rate rose to 4.3 percent, the highest since the European-standard index was introduced in 1997, the Labor Ministry said. Prices jumped even with unemployment rising for a third month, as a softening real estate market led to a 13 percent increase in benefit claims by construction workers, a separate report showed.

headline.main: Spain: Inflation Rate Is Highest in 10 Years

abstract: China will allow only state-run Web sites to broadcast video or radio through the Internet, tightening the government’s regulatory grip over the media content offered there.
snippet: China will allow only state-run Web sites to broadcast video or radio through the Internet, tightening the government’s regulatory grip over the media content offered there.
lead_paragraph: China will allow only state-run Web sites to broadcast video or radio through the Internet, tightening the government’s regulatory grip over the media content offered there. Starting Jan. 31, Internet broadcasting license applicants must be government-run entities, China’s State Administration of Radio, Film and Television said Dec. 29 in a statement posted on its Web site. Operators will be banned from offering content that promotes sex, violence, gambling or religious cults or divulges state secrets, it said. “Internet video and audio providers must be resolute in the service of the socialist ideal and of the people, and regard the interest of overall society as the top priority,” according to a statement from the agency, which will supervise Web video and radio services.

headline.main: China: Restrictions on Web Video and Audio

abstract: The Chicago Sun-Times, the flagship newspaper of the Sun-Times Media Group, has proposed cutting 35 union newsroom positions, or about 19 percent of the paper’s nonmanagement news jobs. The union has two weeks to make a counterproposal and plans to ask Sun-Times management to offer a buyout package, said Misha Davenport, a features writer and co-chairwoman of the Chicago Newspaper Guild. Sun-Times Media, formerly Hollinger International, is under pressure from shareholders to sell the company after revenue fell 10 percent to $279 million last year through Sept. 30.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Sun-Times, the flagship newspaper of the Sun-Times Media Group, has proposed cutting 35 union newsroom positions, or about 19 percent of the paper’s nonmanagement news jobs. The union has two weeks to make a counterproposal and plans to ask Sun-Times management to offer a buyout package, said Misha Davenport, a features writer and co-chairwoman of the Chicago Newspaper Guild. Sun-Times Media, formerly Hollinger International, is under pressure from shareholders to sell the company after revenue fell 10 percent to $279 million last year through Sept. 30.

headline.main: Job Cuts at Sun-Times

abstract: Scottish and Southern Energy, a British utility, agreed to buy the Irish wind farm operator Airtricity for 1.83 billion euros ($2.7 billion) in cash to add to its production of renewable energy. In the deal, Scottish and Southern said it would also take over 375 million euros of debt. The European Union has called for 20 percent of all energy, including transport fuels and heating, to come from renewable sources by 2020. Airtricity, Ireland’s largest wind farm operator, has been expanding operations in Britain and last year won approval to install turbines off the coast of England. Scottish and Southern, based in Perth, Scotland, said the deal would probably be completed in the first quarter.

abstract: Regions Financial, Alabama’s biggest bank, will quadruple its reserve for loan losses, to $360 million, for the fourth quarter because of slowing real estate markets in Florida and Georgia. Regions moved $900 million of its $7.5 billion in loans to residential builders into a special asset pool because of slumping demand for housing, particularly in Miami and Atlanta. The Birmingham, Ala., bank raised its provision for loan losses from $90 million as of Sept. 30, to $360 million, and said it expected losses to increase throughout 2008.

abstract: Pioneer seizes the bragging rights for the highest contrast ratio on a high-definition TV. The company says its black is so black the TV can look like its off when it’s on.
snippet: Pioneer seizes the bragging rights for the highest contrast ratio on a high-definition TV. The company says its black is so black the TV can look like its off when it’s on.
lead_paragraph: When TV manufacturers tout their excellent picture, they often refer to the display’s resolution, the number of pixels it can put on a screen. But image aficionados know that pixels don’t make up the whole picture, so to speak. Equally important to good picture quality is the screen’s contrast ratio, its ability to display a wide range of tones, from dark blacks to white whites.

headline.main: Black Is the Color of My True Love’s TV

abstract: Philips, the dominant electronics maker in Europe, has never had the same kind of success in the United States. But it keeps trying, this time with a lighted bezel for its TV sets.
snippet: Philips, the dominant electronics maker in Europe, has never had the same kind of success in the United States. But it keeps trying, this time with a lighted bezel for its TV sets.
lead_paragraph: Why does Philips–the Dutch electronics and appliance giant–seem to have such difficulty gaining traction in the United States? In Europe, it’s a dominant brand, but its sales in the United States have often prompted expressions of unhappiness from its corporate parent. After pioneering plasma TV in American almost ten years ago, the company, which now concentrates on LCD displays, seems like an also-ran in the TV business in this country.

headline.main: A New Approach for Philips

lead_paragraph: It had all the feeling of a wake, not a celebration. Toshiba, the major proponent and manufacturer of the HD DVD format, tried to put on a good face at Sunday’s C.E.S. press conference, but there was no denying that the decision by Warner Brothers late last week to release future feature films exclusively on Blu-ray clearly took the company by surprise, and may have dealt a fatal blow to its HD DVD format.

lead_paragraph: One tantalizing tidbit from C.E.S. was the revival of a technology from the cable industry that is meant to let any television or other device hook into cable systems without a set-top box. Several manufacturers, including Panasonic, said they would deploy sets using the technology.

abstract: BUSINESS TRAVEL DEMAND UP IN 2008 Any weakening in the economy apparently has not yet affected most business travelers’ plans this year. According to Access America, an insurance and travelers’ assistance company, 26 percent of business travelers surveyed said they expected to be on the road more this year than last, and 61 percent said they expected to travel about the same amount. Among other findings in the survey of 1,000 travelers: Nearly 78 percent cited high gasoline prices as one frustration of travel, 55 percent named poor airline service, and 41 percent cited airport security and passport and border procedures. By far the least frustrating part of travel was booking the trip. Only 16 percent said they found making travel arrangements frustrating.

abstract: Manufacturing orders in Germany unexpectedly surged for a second month in November as domestic companies increased spending on goods such as factory machinery. Orders, adjusted for seasonal swings and inflation, gained 3.4 percent from October, when they rose 4 percent, the Economics and Technology Ministry said. Domestic orders rose 4.2 percent from October and export sales increased 2.8 percent. Orders from the euro area gained 6.8 percent, the report showed. Capital goods orders rose 3.6 percent and sales of intermediate goods advanced 4.3 percent, while demand for consumer goods slid 1.1 percent.

abstract: China will ban retailers from giving free plastic shopping bags to consumers starting in June to curb waste and reduce pollution. China’s cabinet, the State Council, calling the excessive use of plastic bags a “serious” waste of resources, also said it would ban production of ultra-thin plastic bags measuring less than 0.025 millimeter thick. Retailers will be able to sell plastic bags, but will have to clearly display the price and may not include the cost in the price of merchandise, the State Council said.

abstract: European retail sales fell the most in at least 10 years in November as rising food and energy costs sapped consumer confidence. Retail sales declined 1.4 percent in November from a year ago, the biggest drop since at least 1997, the European Union’s statistics office in Luxembourg said. From the previous month, sales fell 0.5 percent, the third decline in four months. Higher gasoline and food costs are eroding purchasing power in the euro area and restraining spending even as unemployment falls to a record low.

abstract: A. P. Moeller-Maersk, the world’s largest ocean cargo carrier, will cut as many as 3,000 jobs in the container division after the unit posted a loss in 2006 for the first time in at least three years. The division, Maersk Line, will reduce its 25,000-member work force by 2,000 to 3,000 people, or as much as 12 percent, the company said. Maersk Line, which owns more than 500 vessels that carry 1.7 million containers, posted a $568 million loss in 2006, its first since Maersk began breaking out division figures in 2003. Moeller-Maersk is based in Copenhagen.

abstract: Alliant Techsystems, a maker of weapons and space systems, said it had agreed to buy a unit of MacDonald, Dettwiler & Associates for 1.33 billion Canadian dollars ($1.34 billion) to build complete satellite systems. Alliant agreed to buy MacDonald’s information systems and geospatial information services group in its biggest acquisition ever and its first outside the United States, said Alliant’s chief executive, Daniel Murphy. The purchase will be complete by the end of March and will add to Alliant’s profit starting in the 2010 fiscal year. Alliant, based in Edina, Minn., will be able to build and operate full satellite systems as sales slow in its main business, supplying bullets to the United States Army. MacDonald is based in Richmond, British Columbia.

lead_paragraph: A new storage device guards against the day when your PC drive takes a dive. The ReadyNAS Duo, announced this week at the Consumer Electronics Show, is made by Netgear and will go on sale in March. Unlike simple single-drive storage connected to one computer with a cable, it is part of the home or office network, so it can be reached by all of the network’s PCs or media players.

Free options include Password Safe (passwordsafe.sourceforge.net) and Password Corral (www.cygnusproductions.com). abstract: Reddy Ice on Wednesday announced that it was in price renegotiations with respect to its pending $1.1 billion purchase by GSO Capital Partners. The announcement comes as the February 3, 2008, termination date for the transaction fast approaches. GSO must decide prior to that date whether to commit to the transaction if it can obtain financing, or terminate on that date and pay a $21 million termination fee. In the latter event, GSO may claim a material adverse change to Reddy Ice under the terms of the merger agreement in order to escape even paying the $21 million reverse termination fee.

abstract: The lack of religious comment to date may not represent nano-ignorance so much as unwillingness to see any spiritual problem with re-engineering the molecular structure of textiles to improve stain resistance.
snippet: The lack of religious comment to date may not represent nano-ignorance so much as unwillingness to see any spiritual problem with re-engineering the molecular structure of textiles to improve stain resistance.
lead_paragraph: There may not be a lot of agreement among the world’s religions on exactly what constitutes humans “playing God,” but you never hear a preacher or rabbi suggesting such behavior is wise or laudable. So you would think they might have a lot to say about nanotechnology. After all, nanotech involves rearranging not just DNA and the other building blocks of life — already a source of controversy in biotechnology — but the very atoms and molecules that make up all matter. If that is not messing around in God’s closet, what is?

headline.main: God and Small Things

lead_paragraph: I COMMITTED to my executive pursuit of snowboarding by deliberately falling down on my butt. It was minus 17 degrees on the slopes of Whiteface Mountain outside Lake Placid, N.Y. My 56-year-old body was wrapped in long johns, a fur-lined jacket and wind pants. With my black rental helmet, amber goggles and black felt face mask, I fancied myself a winterized Power Ranger. I was determined to drop in, air it out and stomp a ride  just as soon as I learned what all of that meant.

Prywes, a partner in the Washington offices of the law firm Bryan Cave. When Mr. Prywes said that soliciting participation in political events might be permissible, he was referring to both employers and employees, not just employees. In addition, he said that employers who coerce employees to make political contributions would be violating federal election laws; he was not referring to employees who solicit contributions.

abstract: With new episodes of ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” and CBS’s “CSI” at 9 p.m. on Thursday, both networks surged to the top of the night’s ratings heap. abstract: In 1991, GQ magazine pronounced his high-flying career in finance finished: “It’s over for Bruce Wasserstein,” the magazine declared. Just a few years ago, that might have seemed prescient. But today, that conclusion seems more than a bit premature, as Karl Taro Greenfeld reports in a generally flattering article about the Lazard chief executive that appears in the February issue of Portfolio magazine.

abstract: NBC’s bare-bones version of the “65th Annual Golden Globes” attracted just 5.8 million viewers on Sunday, a small fraction of the 20 million who tuned in to the awards show a year ago, according to Nielsen’s estimates. A two-hour “Dateline” that preceded the 9 p.m. announcement show and featured interviews with the nominees did not fare any better, attracting just 4.4 million viewers. Combined, the three-hour broadcast delivered a dismal 1.3 rating in the critical demographic of adults 18 to 49, a far cry from the 6.5 rating the show earned in prime time on a Monday last January.

abstract: BIG FARE INCREASES After United Airlines raised domestic fares across the board by $50 a round trip on Friday, most major carriers quickly followed with similar increases on many routes, according to FareCompare.com. The reason was sharply higher fuel costs. Delta Air Lines raised its round-trip fares by $50 immediately after United’s move. American Airlines also posted $50 round-trip increases on 55 percent of its route system, though "conspicuously absent" are increases on its routes that overlap with many Southwest Airlines routes, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive of FareCompare.com. Then on Monday, Northwest Airlines also joined in the $50 increase on most of its routes. Continental Airlines, which initially raised fares by $50 on some routes on Friday, withdrew the increases Monday morning, but Mr. Seaney said it was unclear whether Continental might reverse course again soon. This was the second broad fare increase in 2008, and the 10th since last Labor Day, Mr. Seaney said, adding: "It seems the legacy airlines, United in particular, are forgoing the nickel-and-dime strategy of increases every few weeks and are going for the whole enchilada at one time.".

abstract: Most shareholders like dividends — just ask a Citigroup investor — but creditors generally aren’t big fans. This is especially true of the “special” dividends that private equity firms like to pay to themselves, sometimes just a few months after a leveraged buyout is complete. This sudden outflow of cash can be deeply annoying to bondholders worried about the quality of their debt, which is why Moody’s Investors Service decided to examine which private equity firms tend to be quickest on the draw when it comes to dividends.
lead_paragraph: Most shareholders like dividends — just ask a Citigroup investor — but creditors generally aren’t big fans. This is especially true of the “special” dividends that private equity firms like to pay to themselves, sometimes just a few months after a leveraged buyout is complete. This sudden outflow of cash can be deeply annoying to bondholders worried about the quality of their debt, which is why Moody’s Investors Service decided to examine which private equity firms tend to be quickest on the draw when it comes to dividends.

headline.main: Which Buyout Firms Were Quickest to Cash Out?

abstract: A British group’s announcement that it would not allow its organic label to be used on any product containing synthetic nano-particles is a bit perplexing to people who follow nanotechnology.
snippet: A British group’s announcement that it would not allow its organic label to be used on any product containing synthetic nano-particles is a bit perplexing to people who follow nanotechnology.
lead_paragraph: The Soil Association, Britain’s largest certifier of organic products, issued a press release Tuesday proclaiming itself to be the “first organization in the world to ban nanoparticles.” On closer inspection, that boiled down to the group saying it would not allow its organic label to be used on any product containing synthetic particles with a mean size of less than 200 nanometers or in which the smallest particles were less than 125 nanometers.

headline.main: No Nanoparticles Were Killed Making This Post

abstract: Belgian newspapers, emboldened by a court victory against Google last year, have started a preliminary copyright action against the European Commission over links on agency Web sites. Two Web sites owned by the commission, the Brussels-based executive for the 27 European Union nations, infringe copyright laws by linking to Belgian newspaper articles free, according to Copiepresse, a copyright group for French- and German-language newspapers. A Brussels court, asked by the group to look at its claim, appointed an expert to study how information is gathered for the E.U. sites. “Once the expert has submitted his report, we may decide to file a lawsuit,” said Margaret Boribon, the group’s secretary general. A Brussels court in February ruled Google had violated Belgian copyright laws by publishing links to the newspapers without permission and ordered the company to remove the links or pay a daily fine of 25,000 euros ($37,000).

A Brussels court, asked by the group to look at its claim, appointed an expert to study how information is gathered for the E.U. sites. “Once the expert has submitted his report, we may decide to file a lawsuit,” said Margaret Boribon, the group’s secretary general. A Brussels court in February ruled Google had violated Belgian copyright laws by publishing links to the newspapers without permission and ordered the company to remove the links or pay a daily fine of 25,000 euros ($37,000).

lead_paragraph: Google announced a plan on Thursday that begins to fulfill the pledge it made to investors when it went public nearly four years ago to reserve 1 percent of its profit and equity to “make the world a better place.” The beneficiaries of Google’s money range from groups that are fighting disease to those developing a commercial plug-in car.

headline.print_headline: Google’s Searches Now Include Ways to Make a Better World

abstract: Australian employment rose for a 14th month in December, adding to the longest hiring boom in almost three decades.
snippet: Australian employment rose for a 14th month in December, adding to the longest hiring boom in almost three decades.
lead_paragraph: Australian employment rose for a 14th month in December, adding to the longest hiring boom in almost three decades, which is fanning inflation and may force the central bank to raise borrowing costs next month. The number of people employed climbed by 20,100, after a revised 47,600 gain in November, the Bureau of Statistics said. The jobless rate fell to 4.3 percent from 4.5 percent. “It’s one more tick in the box for our view that the Reserve Bank will probably have to lift rates as early as February,” said John Peters, senior economist at Commonwealth Bank of Australia in Sydney. “An ever-tighter labor market runs the risk of wage inflation.”

headline.main: Australia: Job Growth Stirs Inflation Concern
headline.print_headline: Australia: Job Growth Stirs Inflation Concern

abstract: The shape of the new post housing-bubble market is one that favors young people who never owned a house and the banks that have access to cheap deposits.
snippet: The shape of the new post housing-bubble market is one that favors young people who never owned a house and the banks that have access to cheap deposits.
lead_paragraph: The shape of the new American housing market  the post-bubble market  is starting to emerge. It is one that favors the young who never owned a house and the banks that have access to cheap deposits. It may be harshest on the two coasts, where both distress and a newfound lack of mobility may be on the increase.

headline.main: Sorting Out the New Housing Market
headline.print_headline: To Buy A Home, Be a Renter

abstract: The owner of South Korea’s largest builder and second-biggest airline bid for control of the Korea Express Company to add cargo delivery and warehousing services.
snippet: The owner of South Korea’s largest builder and second-biggest airline bid for control of the Korea Express Company to add cargo delivery and warehousing services.
lead_paragraph: The Kumho-Asiana Group, owner of South Korea’s largest builder and second-biggest airline, bid more than 4 trillion won ($4.3 billion) for control of the Korea Express Company to add cargo delivery and warehousing services. The bidding group comprises about 10 companies, not all of which are controlled by Kumho-Asiana, and is the leading bidder, according to a spokesman for the Seoul Central District Court, where Korea Express has been in receivership since 2001. Korea Express, based in Seoul, fell under court control after failing to pay debts inherited from its parent, the Dongah Construction Industrial Company. It runs warehouses and container ports, as well as handling international door-to-door deliveries.

headline.main: South Korea: Bid Is Made for Shipping Service

abstract: The British mining company Anglo American is in exclusive negotiations to pay $5.5 billion for control of iron ore projects owned by a Brazilian mining concern.
snippet: The British mining company Anglo American is in exclusive negotiations to pay $5.5 billion for control of iron ore projects owned by a Brazilian mining concern.
lead_paragraph: The British mining company Anglo American is in exclusive negotiations to pay $5.5 billion for control of iron ore projects owned by the Brazilian mining concern MMX Mineração e Metálicos, the companies said. Under terms of a complex deal, Anglo American would buy the MMX shares owned by a Brazilian businessman, Eike F. Batista, and secure control of the company’s Minas-Rio and Amapa ore mines in Brazil, the companies said. Anglo American said the talks focused on the acquisition of Mr. Batista’s 63.6 percent share in what would be a new company broken off from MMX. That company would own MMX’s current 51 percent interest in Minas-Rio and 70 percent interest in Amapa. Anglo American would also pay royalties to MMX for the Minas-Rio project beginning in 2025 and beginning in 2023 for Amapa.

headline.main: Brazil: Sale of Iron Ore Projects Is Weighed
headline.print_headline: Brazil: Sale of Iron Ore Projects Is Weighed

lead_paragraph: 1. I was pleased to see this story, “On-ramping not just for women anymore,” by Maggie Jackson in The Boston Globe earlier this week. On-ramping programs that focus on helping women return to work after taking years off for child rearing have been getting a lot of attention, but few people have been writing about the men who go through this same experience. It is a good sign for all of us when something moves from being a women’s issue to an everyone issue. And that usually happens once the men start speaking out.

headline.main: Friday’s Links: Dads Go Back to Work, Freelancers Name Their Rates

abstract: Is the march of technology taking away rights people used to enjoy, such as the ability to make personal copies of things they buy? lead_paragraph: Throughout the debate this week on copyright issues, the question of fair use has come up repeatedly. On Wednesday, the topic for Rick Cotton, the general Counsel of NBC Universal, and Tim Wu, the Columbia law professor, was the legal concept of fair use: how much of a copyrighted work can be included in a review or other sort of work. But in many of the comments we received all week, readers have asked about their own broader sense that when they buy a CD or movie, they purchase rights that include making copies for their personal use.

abstract: The Brazilian state oil company said it had discovered a natural gas reserve off the coast of Rio de Janeiro that could be as big as the recently discovered giant Tupi oil field. The company, Petróleo Brasileiro, said the potential reserves were about three miles below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean, 23 miles west of the Tupi field. The release did not provide figures as to the size of the reserve but said its structure could have dimensions that are similar to Tupi’s. Late last year, Petrobras announced the discovery of as much as eight billion barrels of light crude oil in the ultra-deep Tupi field.

abstract: Major airlines have raised fares again, a week after a round of $50 round-trip fare increases collapsed when Continental Airlines rescinded its increases, causing all the others to back off as well.
snippet: Major airlines have raised fares again, a week after a round of $50 round-trip fare increases collapsed when Continental Airlines rescinded its increases, causing all the others to back off as well.
lead_paragraph: FARE INCREASES ON AGAIN Major airlines have raised fares again, a week after a round of $50 round-trip fare increases collapsed when Continental Airlines rescinded its increases, causing all the others to back off as well. But on Thursday, American Airlines instituted a new increase of $40 round trip, citing fuel costs. Delta matched, and the others fell in line over the weekend, according to Tom Parsons, chief executive officer of Bestfares.com. Mr. Parsons said that business travelers booking flights at the last minute have been hard hit by incremental fare increases in recent years. "Since January 2005, business travelers who purchase tickets with little or no advance purchase have taken the brunt of increases in airfares,” he said.

abstract: Antitrust regulators in the European Union have stepped up a review of International Business Machines’ proposed $4.9 billion bid for Cognos, a maker of business-analysis software. The European Commission said in a statement that the transaction’s combined market share was above certain thresholds for a simplified review. The commission did not change its Jan. 29 deadline to rule on the deal. The transaction “no longer fulfills the criteria for simplified procedure,” said Jonathan Todd, a commission spokesman.

abstract: Negotiators for the European Union and the United States said that they hoped a meeting of trade ministers in Davos, Switzerland, this week could help restart global trade talks and pave the way for a deal. Begun in 2001 to help increase trade and develop the economies of poorer countries, the talks have already missed a succession of deadlines. The European trade commissioner, Peter Mandelson, sought to increase pressure for a breakthrough after a meeting on Monday with Susan C. Schwab, above, the United States trade representative. “We are rapidly moving toward a moment of truth,” Mr. Mandelson said.

abstract: Royal Philips Electronics, the lighting and health care giant, said that fourth-quarter profit doubled to 1.39 billion euros ($2.03 billion) from 680 million for the same quarter a year ago, while sales rose 3.8 percent to 8.37 billion euros ($12.2 billion). Philips said its profit included gains from the 1.09 billion-euro ($1.60 billion) sale of stakes in several other companies, offset by 404 million euros ($591 million) in one-time charges. The medical equipment unit remained the most profitable, with earnings up 9.9 percent to 322 million euros ($471 million), despite a 2 percent fall in sales. The unit’s operating profit rose 34 percent to 170 million euros ($249 million) on a sales rise of 14 percent.

abstract: Sanyo, the electronics maker, will sell its troubled cellphone operations to a rival, Kyocera. The companies said the value of the business is about 40 billion yen ($374 million). Including debt, the deal — set for completion April 1 — is worth about 50 billion yen ($467 million), although the companies have yet to agree on a final price. The long-anticipated sale of the unit comes months after Goldman Sachs and other investors saved Sanyo in a 300 billion yen ($2.8 billion) bailout.

abstract: Stocks looked ready to plunge in the United States early Tuesday, as the waves of anxious selling in Asian markets threatened to spread to Wall Street. Before the open of regular trading, Dow Jones Industrial Average futures were down more than 500 points, amid fears that the economic troubles in the United States were deeper and more far-reaching than previously thought. That was before the Federal Reserve announced early Tuesday it would cut its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point.

snippet: Amid U.S. market volatility, some analysts say the European Central Bank’s focus on inflation may be misplaced.
lead_paragraph: LONDON  Monetary policy usually takes some time to bite. That is one explanation for the American stock market’s continued gyrations on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve’s emergency rate cut. It may also explain why the European Central Bank has given no indication that it will follow suit.

headline.main: Why the European Bank Is Sitting Back

abstract: A call to readers to submit their work/life strategies.
snippet: A call to readers to submit their work/life strategies.
lead_paragraph: I took that two-week, nonworking vacation and now I’m paying for it. Aside from one prewritten blog post, I didn’t plan ahead for the work that was awaiting me. So I came home, in the middle of a week, in need of two doctor visits to deal with trip-related maladies. My desk, clean when I left, quickly became a jumble of work stuff and personal bills, all vying for my attention. In the next three weeks, I have business travel, family responsibilities and a few more deadlines than usual. I worked through my first weekend back, and I’m likely to do the same next weekend (on top of taking a business trip).

headline.main: Work/Life Balance — How Do You Do It?

abstract: It was an aptly named dinner debate on this first day of gloom and doom at the World Economic Forum: “Recession,” the title read in the forum’s program folder in bold red letters as if to drive home the point. After a day of debates dedicated to (or inevitably turning to) the United States economy’s sorry outlook, two high-profile chief executives joked that it felt like an act of masochism to end the day like this (rather than at the simultaneous wine-tasting or story-telling dinners).

abstract: If you are listening to Audible books and spoken-word content on your iPod, you can often change the pace.

lead_paragraph: Some audiobook narrators talk too fast  and some too slow. If you are listening to Audible books and spoken-word content on your iPod, you can often change the pace. Just go to the Settings area on the iPod’s main menu and choose Audiobooks. On the next screen, you can adjust the playback speed of the file to Slower, Normal or Faster. You do not have to worry about your book sounding like someone reading underwater or narrating like a chipmunk the setting you select will not alter the pitch of the narrator’s voice.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Adjusting the Pace of Your Audiobook

abstract: Russians, like blondes, have more fun. At least that was the impression at a party hosted Thursday night by the Russian investment firm Troika Dialog. Olympic ice skating stars were imported for the night, and guests were invited to try their luck with these supremos of the rink. Then they twirled and spun their way through well-known Russian folk tunes, with at least 200 spectators clapping along, fortified by vodka and gluehwein! In an after-party in a rink-side tent, there were possibly more billionaires per square foot than anywhere else, even in the town of Davos.

abstract: Facing minimal competition on Thursday, two episodes of “Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?” gave Fox a slight victory in the night’s ratings among adults 18 to 49. Drawing 10.5 million viewers at 8 p.m. and 10.2 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates, the quiz show also delivered some of the night’s largest audiences overall, trailing only CBS’s repeats at 9 and 10 p.m. of “CSI” (13.3 million) and “Without a Trace” (11.7 million), respectively.

abstract: The last thing I saw before plunging down the bobsled track at the Olympic Sports Complex outside Lake Placid, N.Y., was an eerie orange light.
snippet: The last thing I saw before plunging down the bobsled track at the Olympic Sports Complex outside Lake Placid, N.Y., was an eerie orange light.
lead_paragraph: THE last thing I saw before plunging down the bobsled track at the Olympic Sports Complex outside Lake Placid, N.Y., was an eerie orange light. I shivered in a wind chill of minus 17 degrees that penetrated all the way from my crash helmet to my long johns. I realized that the orange light was the sunset reflecting off the summit of Whiteface Mountain a dozen or so miles to the north. But I had no idea whether it foreboded the thrill of a lifetime or imminent death.

headline.main: A Light at the End of the Half-Pipe, Through Closed Eyes
headline.print_headline: A Light at the End Of the Half-Pipe, Through Closed Eyes

abstract: Dr. Robert Pai is optimistic about the fluorescent industry’s chances of developing light bulbs that please everyone and meet the efficiency standards that Congress has mandated for 2012.
snippet: Dr. Robert Pai is optimistic about the fluorescent industry’s chances of developing light bulbs that please everyone and meet the efficiency standards that Congress has mandated for 2012.
lead_paragraph: SOME 26 years ago, when Robert Pai joined Sylvania’s fluorescent technology laboratories, he and his fellow researchers did not think much about compact fluorescents. They were more interested in solving problems with mercury and ballast, and otherwise making big industrial fluorescent lamps more efficient and safer for the environment. Much has happened since. Sylvania is now part of Osram Sylvania, a unit of the German company Siemens. Dr. Pai  he has a doctorate in physics  is heading compact fluorescent research. And compact fluorescents, usually called C.F.L.’s, are definitely on researchers’ minds.

headline.main: Seeking a More Flattering Light on, and From, Bulbs

abstract: There has probably never been service like it! About 40 women congregated Friday night in the cozy wooden chalet restaurant of the Davos Golf Club and heard Queen Rania of Jordan, Sarah Brown (as in wife of Gordon, Prime Minister of Britain), Indra K. Nooyi, CEO of PepsiCo, Wendi Murdoch, the rock star Annie Lennox and the ”best dressed woman at Davos,” the former Nigerian finance minister Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, make powerful appeals for concerted action to cut down maternal mortality. Among those listening: Cherie Booth (as in wife of Tony Blair, Gordon’s predecessor), Ann Veneman of UNICEF and leaders of charities like Oxfam and Save the Children.

abstract: Managers won’t get $87 million for exiting bankruptcy.

lead_paragraph: MORE than two years ago, the Delphi Corporation, an automotive parts giant, filed for bankruptcy protection. Even as it asked workers, creditors and owners to accept big losses, Delphi requested a lush executive pay package that included $87 million in cash bonuses to be paid to top managers upon the company’s exit from bankruptcy. It was a wonderful example of unshared sacrifice that has become deplorably common in corporate America.

Other reports will include new home sales for December (Monday); durable goods for December and the Conference Board consumer confidence index for January (Tuesday); the first estimate of fourth-quarter gross domestic product and the ADP employment forecast (Wednesday); personal income and spending for December and the Chicago purchasing managers index for January (Thursday); and reports on unemployment for January, the Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing index for January, construction spending for December and the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index (Friday).

abstract: Kellwood, the apparel company that makes the Baby Phat line of clothing, will remove all barriers to a cash tender offer of $21 a share made by the private equity firm Sun Capital so that the deal can be concluded if a majority of the shares are tendered, the company said on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Kellwood, the apparel company that makes the Baby Phat line of clothing, will remove all barriers to a cash tender offer of $21 a share made by the private equity firm Sun Capital so that the deal can be concluded if a majority of the shares are tendered, the company said on Sunday.

headline.main: Kellwood Lowers Defenses to Sun Capital Bid

abstract: Last night the Kellwood board of directors did the most unusual thing. Throwing out their ’80s playbook, the board simply folded in the wake of Sun Capital‘s bid. The board announced that it intends to remove all impediments to the $21 per share hostile tender offer being made by the Sun Capital Securities Group. Kellwood said it would permit Sun to freely close its Feb. 12 tender offer if a majority of Kellwood’s shares are tendered into the offer.

lead_paragraph: When I was deciding whether to go to law school, I read Scott Turow’s “One L.” Everyone did. You bought it along with your LSAT prep materials. Today, we still have memoirs that give a window into the life in a profession (like the recent “Diary of a Real Estate Rookie,” by Alison Rogers or Atul Gawande’s articles and books about a life in medicine). But if I were considering being a lawyer today, I’d be looking for blogs that offer a regular glimpse of a life in the law, like this one by Evan Schaeffer, offering tips and techniques for trial lawyers.

lead_paragraph: We tend to think of the “innovator’s dilemma,” a term coined by the Harvard Business school professor Clayton M. Christensen, as something that affects large companies. It refers to disruptive innovations — for example, digital photography — which existing businesses — for example, Kodak — are often reluctant to embrace because they could harm their core businesses. It’s a failure that often leads to the downfall of great companies, Mr. Christensen argued in his best-selling book “The Innovator’s Dilemma.”

headline.main: The Innovator’s Dilemma of a Toy Maker

abstract: Saying that Internet and technology companies have for too long had a “free ride on music,” the veteran manager of the band U2 urged them to start “sharing their enormous revenue” with singers and songwriters. At the annual music industry trade show in the south of France, the manager, Paul McGuinness, blamed broadband Internet service providers in particular for allowing mass piracy of digital music over their networks while sales of recorded music and royalty payments to musicians have plunged. Global music sales have fallen to $17.6 billion last year from $38 billion in 1998, according to industry estimates. Mr. McGuinness endorsed a proposal first raised in France late last year for Internet service providers to voluntarily band together and crack down on subscribers who dominate illegal file-sharing networks.

abstract: Nokia, a cellphone maker, said it had agreed to buy Trolltech, a Norwegian software company that makes products that create applications that work on different operating systems, for 844 million Norwegian kroner ($154 million). Nokia, based in Finland, said Trolltech’s set of software development tools would allow it to create new applications compatible with the operating systems on its mobile phones. Nokia’s purchase of Trolltech, founded in 1994, followed its $8.1 billion acquisition in August of Navteq, an American maker of digital map data. Trolltech, based in Oslo, reported a loss of 48.7 million kroner in 2006, the last year for which full-year figures were available, on sales of 174 million kroner.

abstract: Banco Bradesco, the Brazilian bank, reported a 29 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income on higher lending and one-time gains. Net income climbed to 2.19 billion reais ($1.23 billion) from 1.7 billion reais a year earlier, Bradesco said. Recurring profit, similar to profit from continuing operations, advanced 14 percent to 1.85 billion reais from a year ago, it said. Bank lending in Brazil has increased every month since February 2004 as interest rates fell to record lows and employment rose. The total loan portfolio, including receivables from credit cards, grew 39 percent to 161.4 billion reais, from 116.2 billion in December 2006. Net income was helped by a one-time 227-million-reais gain from the sale of a stake in Bolsa de Mercadorias & Futuros, Latin America’s largest derivatives market, and 178 million reais of profit from the sale of shares in Bovespa Holding, owner of São Paulo’s stock exchange.

Recurring profit, similar to profit from continuing operations, advanced 14 percent to 1.85 billion reais from a year ago, it said. Bank lending in Brazil has increased every month since February 2004 as interest rates fell to record lows and employment rose. The total loan portfolio, including receivables from credit cards, grew 39 percent to 161.4 billion reais, from 116.2 billion in December 2006. Net income was helped by a one-time 227-million-reais gain from the sale of a stake in Bolsa de Mercadorias & Futuros, Latin America’s largest derivatives market, and 178 million reais of profit from the sale of shares in Bovespa Holding, owner of São Paulo’s stock exchange.

headline.main: Brazil: Bank’s Lending and Profit Rise

lead_paragraph: AIRPORT EFFORT ON CUSTOMER SERVICE A program to improve airport workers’ customer service skills started last week at Kennedy International Airport and is expected to be expanded nationally under the name Aviation Resiliency Project. The initial phase of the project  which is being run by the Reclaiming the Sky Institute, a nonprofit group that aims to support aviation workers, along with Fordham University  has about 300 participants at Kennedy. They will receive extra training in “resiliency skills” to better handle passengers distressed over flight delays and cancellations. Findings of the pilot project will be compiled in March.

abstract: The prime minister of Ukraine, Yulia Tymoshenko, below, demanded that Gazprom, the Russian natural gas monopoly, deal directly with the Ukrainian state oil and gas company rather than through an intermediary as it does now. The demand could unravel a natural gas trade agreement that settled a dispute between Ukraine and Gazprom two years ago. That agreement set up the intermediary, RosUkrEnergo, to buy gas from Gazprom and sell it at a loss to Ukraine and then recover the loss by selling gas in Europe at a higher price or blending gas with lower-cost gas from central Asia. Europe buys about 25 percent of its gas from Gazprom, and about 25 percent of it is shipped through Ukraine. In another sign that the deal may be unwinding, the Russian police last week arrested Semyon Mogilevich, a reputed organized-crime figure with ties to RosUkrEnergo, though on tax-evasion charges unrelated to the Ukrainian gas business.

abstract: Extreme temperatures have frozen equipment and forced a shutdown at Syncrude Canada, the oil sands project. Most of the 350,000 barrels of oil produced daily at the project are sent to the United States. But temperatures in northern Alberta, where Syncrude is located, have dipped below minus 40 degrees at night this week. That has led to “several instrument freeze-ups,” the Canadian Oil Sands Trust, which owns about 37 percent of the project, said on Tuesday. Full production will probably not resume for several days.

abstract: President Óscar Arias of Costa Rica, below, said he would ask the United States to delay the start of a free-trade agreement to give the country time to pass several local laws. Costa Rica approved the Central American Free Trade Agreement in October, but its Congress has passed only 4 of 13 laws necessary to begin it, Mr. Arias said. The deadline for doing so is Feb. 29 and Mr. Arias acknowledged that his administration would not be ready by that date. The pact has already taken effect in the Dominican Republic, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and El Salvador.

abstract: The Luxottica Group, the Italian maker of eyeglasses, said fourth-quarter sales rose 7.1 percent after last year’s acquisition of Oakley. Revenue at the company, which operates Sunglass Hut and LensCrafter stores and makes Ray-Ban sunglasses, climbed to 1.19 billion euros ($1.8 billion) from 1.11 billion euros a year earlier. Fourth-quarter wholesale sales rose 16 percent to 479 million euros ($705 million). Sales fell 1.7 percent at retail stores open at least a year, reflecting Luxottica’s exposure in the United States. Luxottica bought Oakley for $2 billion in June.

abstract: In a move that will make it the country’s largest oil sands producer, Suncor Energy said it would spend 20.6 billion Canadian dollars (about the same in American dollars) to expand operations near Fort McMurray, Alberta. The operation will be able to produce 550,000 barrels of oil a day when completed in 2012. The chief executive of Suncor, Richard L. George, said that with the new project, the company expects to generate a 15 percent return on investment at an oil price of $60 a barrel. The expansion will also allow Suncor to use an underground steam heating process rather than open-pit mining for about half of its tar sands oil production, which will reduce the effect on the environment.

abstract: E.On-Energie, the electrical unit of the energy giant E.On, was fined $56 million by the European Union for a broken seal that had been placed across an office door during an antitrust investigation. The European Commission said the broken seal meant E.On had the chance to remove documents after a raid in May 2006 — although it could not prove that the company had deliberately tampered with the seal or removed anything. E.On said it would appeal the fine. Regulators sealed the door to make sure no documents could be removed. When they returned the next day, signs of tampering showed that someone had removed the tape and tried to put it back, regulators said.

abstract: The European Commission proposed simpler food labels highlighting fat, sugar and salt content in an effort to contain the spread of obesity and junk food. Under the proposals, six content elements will have to appear on packages: energy, total fat, saturated fat, carbohydrates, sugar and salts. The labels will indicate what percentage of advisable daily intake they represent. “Consumers have to be able to make the right choice. They need the right information to plan their diet,” the health commissioner Markos Kyprianou, above, said. The proposals exclude beer, wine and spirits. They will now be taken up by the European Parliament and must be approved by member nations.

abstract: Bidding on the most attractive block of wireless frequencies in the government auction exceeded the $4.6 billion minimum this morning. That means the United States Treasury is likely to take in at least $12 billion from the auction.
snippet: Bidding on the most attractive block of wireless frequencies in the government auction exceeded the $4.6 billion minimum this morning. That means the United States Treasury is likely to take in at least $12 billion from the auction.
lead_paragraph: A bid of $4.7 billion this morning for the most valuable group of wireless licenses in the Federal Communications Commission auction for 700Mhz spectrum pushed the price over the minimum price the government set. That means that the government is likely to receive over $12 billion for the block of spectrum that is being abandoned next year as television broadcasters move permanently to new digital frequencies. The government has said it hoped to earn at least $10 billion from the auction.

headline.main: Spectrum Auction: C Block Hits Reserve Price

abstract: With no new bids in the most recent round, the bidding has paused at $4.7 billion for the C Block, the most attractive group of frequencies the government is auctioning off. The name of the winning bidder won’t be known until the rest of the auction finishes, which could take several weeks.
snippet: With no new bids in the most recent round, the bidding has paused at $4.7 billion for the C Block, the most attractive group of frequencies the government is auctioning off. The name of the winning bidder won’t be known until the rest of the aucti...
lead_paragraph: UPDATE: This post was wrong in saying that rules prohibit anyone from bidding higher than $4.7 billion for the C block. There are some rather complex ways that another company could in fact raise the bid in coming days. I’ll write a post explaining this later.

headline.main: Spectrum Auction: The C-Block Bidding Stalls at $4.7 Billion

abstract: The return of “Lost” — albeit a two-hour repeat of the last season finale — buoyed ABC’s ratings on a night otherwise dominated by Fox’s “American Idol” and “Moment of Truth.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two Fox programs delivered the night’s largest audiences by far, 25.3 million viewers at 8 p.m. for “American Idol” followed by 17.9 million for “The Moment of Truth” at 9 p.m.

lead_paragraph: By most accounts, Jerry Yang, the co-founder and chief executive of Yahoo, is well liked inside the company.
